explanation:
Rationale for each symbol:

- OS_TranslatePath (implementation): OS_mkdir calls this function and it may contain for-loops. To decide if any for-loop inside OS_TranslatePath is well-formed (MISRA rule), you must inspect its loop header clauses and any functions invoked from inside its loop bodies (the rule counts behaviour of called functions as part of the loop body).

- OS_DirCreate_Impl (implementation): This is the other direct callee of OS_mkdir and might itself contain for-loops. Its implementation must be checked the same way as for OS_TranslatePath.

- OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN (macro / constant): Used to size local_path. If any loops iterate using buffer length or are bounded by this constant (in OS_mkdir or in callees that use the buffer), the numeric value/definition is required to assess loop counters, bounds and potential side-effects.

- OS_SUCCESS (macro / enum / constant): Used in the return-code check. While not directly about for-loops, its definition may affect control flow (e.g., early returns) that determine whether callees with loops are executed; include to fully understand control-flow relevant to loop presence.

- int32 / uint32 (typedefs): The types of return_code and access/parameters. Knowing exact typedefs (signedness/width) is useful when checking whether loop counters or expressions (in callees) use compatible integer types or cause implicit conversions that impact loop behaviour.

- OS_printf (implementation / prototype): Called by OS_TranslatePath per the call graph. If OS_TranslatePath uses OS_printf inside a for-loop, the behaviour of OS_printf (side-effects, global state modification) is part of the loop body and must be considered by the MISRA rule (second clause must have no persistent side-effects and third clause must not modify objects changed in the body).

- OS_strnlen (implementation / prototype): Called by OS_TranslatePath; could be used in loop conditions or bodies. Its semantics and whether it has side-effects matter for verifying the second-clause/side-effect constraints.

- OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch, OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, OS_ObjectIdRelease (implementations / prototypes): These are callees of OS_TranslatePath per the graph. If any are invoked inside a for-loop in OS_TranslatePath (or inside nested callees), their behaviour (modifying global/state/objects) must be examined because the rule forbids loop conditions/clauses that depend on or have persistent side-effects on objects modified in the loop body.

Notes: The static call graph also lists several unit-test stub helpers (UT_Stub_*) that appear due to test harnessing. Include those only if you are analyzing a build where the unit-test stubs are linked into the final code: their implementations would need the same scrutiny if they can be invoked from inside any for-loop encountered in the above implementations.
